data.description: Definition, incidence, etiology, and prevention of developmental disabilities. Examines the life-cycle needs of this population, as well as social-welfare issues, social services available, and the social worker's role.
data.title: ISSUES IN DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES

data.description: Research and thesis for MSW students who who wish to submit a master's thesis or conduct independent research.
data.title: THESIS-RESEARCH

data.description: The relationship of parent and child; the rights of unmarried mothers and fathers and their children; parental rights to custody vis a vis third parties; parents' rights to make decisions affecting children; neglect; termination of parental rights; the foster care system and adoption.
data.title: FAMILY LAW: PARENT AND CHILD

data.description: A comprehensive introduction to practice of program evaluation research in social welfare and human development. Developments in descriptive, experimental, quasi-experimental, theory-driven, and naturalistic evaluations detailed. Topics include assessment, evaluation design, monitoring, outcome evaluation, selection bias, program theory, meta-analysis and utilization.
data.title: EVALUATION RESEARCH

data.description: A multi-level exploration of out-of-home care and permanency in the child welfare field.  Includes local, state and national perspectives, as well as research, policy and practice issues in foster care, kinship care, adoption and other permanency options.
data.title: CHILD WELFARE PRACTICE IN FOSTER AND KINSHIP CARE, PERMANENCY, AND ADOPTION

data.description: Addresses major mental health concerns across the lifespan, using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) as the organizing framework for reviewing major mental disorders and critiquing the current "medical model" approach to mental health in the United States. Approaches mental health issues from a generalist perspective, including the role of the social environment, culture, and stigma in mental health services, access, and policy.
data.title: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY IN GENERALIST SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE

data.description: Addresses multi-level interventions with children, youth, and families across multiple service systems, with an emphasis on practice innovations.
data.title: INTERVENTIONS WITH CHILDREN, YOUTH, AND FAMILIES

data.description: Addressing psychosocial, cultural, existential, ethical, and team-based aspects of care with individuals and families across the life course who are impacted by serious illness.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE IN PALLIATIVE CARE

data.description: Advanced practice and coursework in educational settings to conceptualize social work skills in schools and to integrate knowledge of social work theory and practice.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE IN SCHOOLS II

data.description: Advanced practice knowledge and skills essential for social workers practicing in health, aging, and disability care settings.
data.title: HEALTH, AGING, AND DISABILITY PRACTICE FOR THE 21ST CENTURY

data.description: Affirming social work practice with lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, nonbinary, queer, intersex, asexual, Two-Spirit, and other LGBTQIA2S+ individuals and communities.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE WITH LGBTQIA2S+ INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES

data.description: An approved advanced generalist field seminar and placement linked to areas of focus. Seminar and placement require a minimum of 20 hours per week.
data.title: FIELD PRACTICE AND INTEGRATIVE SEMINAR III

data.description: An approved advanced practice social work field seminar and placement.
data.title: FIELD PRACTICE AND INTEGRATIVE SEMINAR IV

data.description: An approved generalist field seminar and social work agency placement. Seminar and placement require a minimum of 16 hours per week. The second course of the two-semester generalist field sequence.
data.title: FIELD PRACTICE AND INTEGRATIVE SEMINAR II

data.description: An approved generalist field seminar and social work community agency placement. Seminar and placement require a minimum of 16 hours/week. The first course of the two-semester generalist field sequence.
data.title: FIELD PRACTICE AND INTEGRATIVE SEMINAR I

data.description: An introduction to the paradigms, methods and substance of sociology.
data.title: HONORS INTRODUCTORY SEMINAR-THE SOCIOLOGICAL ENTERPRISE

data.description: An opportunity to meet with prevention professionals and scholars from across campus and the community to explore current and emerging issues of prevention research and professional practice.  Students must completeHDFS/​ED PSYCH/​NURSING/​SOC WORK  880before taking this course.
data.title: CAPSTONE SEMINAR IN PREVENTION SCIENCE

data.description: An overview of risk and protective factors, theories, services, research, and activism related to interpersonal violence. Models of prevention and intervention will be discussed. Skills related to social work practice with individuals and communities affected by interpersonal violence will be practiced.
data.title: INTERPERSONAL VIOLENCE

data.description: An overview of statistical methods covering the topics required for social work professional degrees, such as distributions, standard error, regression, correlation assumptions and limitations, and basic ideas of experimental design.
data.title: BASIC STATISTICS FOR SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Analysis of policy issues as applied to such fields as poverty, discrimination, crime, physical and mental health on both national and state levels.
data.title: SOCIAL POLICY

data.description: Anti-oppressive approaches to analyzing the dynamics of sex trading (including sex trafficking and sex work) as well as implications for practice and policy. Integrates diverse and conflicting perspectives of survivors, practitioners, and researchers to deconstruct sex trafficking risk, prevention, identification, and intervention strategies.
data.title: SEX TRAFFICKING AND SEX TRADING

data.description: Application of research methods seminars. Practical experience and application of research knowledge and skills. Applied data analysis, proposal and grant Writing, and research methods in communities of color are examples of topics addressed.
data.title: PHD PROSEMINAR

data.description: Applied theory seminars.  Provide a model of the application of social theory to social problems. Adult Mental Health; Microeconomic Theory Applied to Social Problems; and Child Welfare are examples of topics offered.
data.title: PHD PROSEMINAR

data.description: Basic principles and definitions of sociology. Readings and discussion of the perspectives of sociology, the individual and society, groups and social process, stratification, organizations and power, demography, and social change.
data.title: THE SOCIOLOGICAL ENTERPRISE

data.description: Considers legislation, policies, and institutional structures that affect children, youth, and families across multiple service systems.
data.title: CHILD, YOUTH, AND FAMILY POLICIES AND SERVICES

data.description: Course for students in the Part-Time MSW Program to maintain UW-Madison status when they have partial exemptions and no other courses available.
data.title: PART-TIME MSW PROGRAM EXEMPTION TERM

data.description: Develops advanced practice knowledge and skills for social workers practicing in health and health care settings.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE IN HEALTH CARE

data.description: Develops generalist social work knowledge and skills for working with and on behalf of individuals, families, and groups. Focus on development of basic social work direct practice skills.
data.title: GENERALIST PRACTICE WITH INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES AND GROUPS

data.description: Dissertation preparation.
data.title: THESIS-RESEARCH

data.description: Evidence-based cognitive and behavioral interventions used by social workers in the treatment of mental health challenges.
data.title: COGNITIVE AND BEHAVIORAL MENTAL HEALTH TREATMENTS FOR ADULTS

data.description: Examination of physical, emotional and sexual abuse of children, child neglect, and exploitation.
data.title: CHILD ABUSE AND NEGLECT

data.description: Examine ideas and values related to making a difference, think critically about the meaning and methods of changing the world, and integrate thoughtful evidence with your values and beliefs about doing good in the world. With a focus on the profession of social work and other helping professions, consider a variety of social problems, and investigate and critique various approaches to creating change to improve social problems.
data.title: SO YOU WANT TO CHANGE THE WORLD?

data.description: Exploration and application of theory to the formation and development of small groups deliberately used by social workers to effect specified change in interpersonal relationships.
data.title: SMALL GROUPS IN SOCIAL WORK  PRACTICE

data.description: Exploration of the small group as the interventive unit; major models and techniques; principles guiding the selection of the small group approach to intervention based on research knowledge of problems, processes, and outcomes.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK WITH THE SMALL GROUP

data.description: Explore evidence-based services through a holistic perspective that looks at a person in their environment, using a person-centered approach.  Assessment, treatment, and generalization of change strategies; problem solving; resource development; intervention planning; current trends in mental health and other practice issues are explored.
data.title: ASSESSING AND TREATING CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS

data.description: Explore multiple approaches social workers use to foster social justice across organizations, communities, and societal levels. Practice advanced skills for addressing complex macro level practice issues.
data.title: ADVANCED MACRO PRACTICE

data.description: Explores the nature and centrality of the experience of loss and subsequent grief, preparing individuals with strategies to intervene with individuals, families, and communities in response to a diversity of losses throughout the lifespan.
data.title: GRIEF, DEATH, LOSS, AND LIFE

data.description: Exposes students to the theory and practice of planned change in communities and organizations and helps them incorporate a generalist model into practice at these levels of intervention.
data.title: GENERALIST PRACTICE WITH COMMUNITIES AND ORGANIZATIONS

data.description: First of two semesters of undergraduate research for students in the honors program leading to completion of thesis.
data.title: SENIOR HONORS THESIS

data.description: First of two semesters of undergraduate research leading to completion of thesis.
data.title: SENIOR THESIS

data.description: Focused work on a topic or problem of graduate student interest under supervision of social work instructors.
data.title: INDEPENDENT READING

data.description: Focuses on a biopsychosocial understanding of mental health from a social work and social environment perspective, giving special attention to the person-in-environment and current classification systems available to the practitioner.
data.title: PSYCHOPATHOLOGY FOR SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE IN MENTAL HEALTH

data.description: Focuses on the core practice theories, conceptual frameworks, and intervention skills necessary for social work practice in mental health.
data.title: ADVANCED SOC WORK PRACTICE IN MENTAL HEALTH

data.description: Foundational knowledge for generalist social work practice in a multicultural society. Examines the experiences of diverse populations with interpersonal and institutional oppression, and implications are drawn for social policy.
data.title: DIVERSITY, OPPRESSION AND SOCIAL JUSTICE IN SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Foundational knowledge of contemporary psychedelic healing and integration practices.
data.title: PRINCIPLES OF PSYCHEDELIC HEALING

data.description: Foundational preparation for social work practice in a multicultural society. Examines the experiences of diverse populations with interpersonal and institutional oppression and implications are drawn for social policy.
data.title: DIVERSITY, OPPRESSION AND SOCIAL JUSTICE IN SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Furthers the socialization of students to the Ph.D. program. Provides opportunities for faculty to discuss research interests and doctoral education.
data.title: FACULTY RESEARCH SEMINAR

data.description: Gain foundational knowledge and skills in interprofessional collaborative practice and HIV care. Explore the roles of medicine, nursing, pharmacy, and social work in the HIV care continuum. Discuss quality team-based care as a member of an interprofessional student team.
data.title: INTERPROFESSIONAL COLLABORATIVE PRACTICE IN HIV CARE

data.description: Historical development, formation of social welfare policies, and the role of the social work professional.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO THE FIELD OF SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Implications of knowledge from the social and behavioral sciences and public welfare policy on child welfare problems and services.
data.title: CHILD WELFARE

data.description: Independent study for MSW graduate students.
data.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY

data.description: Independent study for undergraduates under the direction of a Social Work instructor. Only juniors and seniors will be given permission to enroll.
data.title: DIRECTED STUDY

data.description: Intensive study of selected topics in the field of social work.
data.title: SPECIAL TOPICS IN SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Interdisciplinary team care of children with special health care needs across the trajectory of illness presented within the context of family, culture, social determinants of health, community, and healthcare policy.   Students introduced to interdisciplinary, collaborative, family-centered team care.
data.title: INTERDISCIPLINARY CARE OF CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL HEALTH CARE NEEDS

data.description: Introduction to health care systems. Factors affecting health and the value placed on health, the delivery of health care in different settings, the roles of various health workers, and the sociological and economic aspects of health care.
data.title: HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS: INTERDISCIPLINARY APPROACH

data.description: Introduction to the complex issues surrounding homelessness in America including epidemiology, demographics, history and public beliefs and attitudes. It explores structural conditions and personal attributes posited as causes of contemporary homelessness. Varying social policies and service needs of homeless persons are discussed.
data.title: HOMELESSNESS: A SERVICE LEARNING COURSE

data.description: Introduction to the field of American sociology, its subfields and specialized areas of research, theoretical traditions and research methods.
data.title: SURVEY OF SOCIOLOGY

data.description: Learn patterns, principles and methods of supervision and consultation.
data.title: SUPERVISION AND LEADERSHIP IN SOCIAL WORK AND HUMAN SERVICES ORGANIZATIONS

data.description: Learn to work with individuals impacted by substance misuse. The history, current understanding, assessment, and treatment of problematic substance use will be described.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK AND SUBSTANCE MISUSE

data.description: Marriage and less formal spousal relationships, husband-wife relationships in on-going marriage; divorce and its economic and custody consequences; post-divorce relationships.
data.title: FAMILY LAW: MARRIAGE AND DIVORCE

data.description: Meaning of crisis to client systems and social work practitioners; principles guiding rational decision to intervene at the point of "critical incident".
data.title: CRISIS INTERVENTION

data.description: Nature and dimensions of poverty in the U.S. Individual and social consequences of poverty. Historic and contemporary approaches. Poverty and social welfare policy and programs.
data.title: POVERTY AND SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Nature, purpose, function, and organizational content of the profession. Historical development; a consideration of the development of the social welfare institutions, formation of social welfare policies and their impact on practice, and the role of the social work professional.
data.title: THE FIELD OF SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Origins, nature, scope and dynamics of the social problems of older adults and their families in the U.S. and to acquaint students with programs and services available to older adults.
data.title: SOCIAL ISSUES IN AGING

data.description: Physiological, psychological, and social changes throughout the life cycle. Major crisis and developmental tasks at each point in terms of their implications for social work practice.
data.title: HUMAN BEHAVIOR AND THE ENVIRONMENT

data.description: Practice and coursework in educational settings to conceptualize social work skills in schools and to integrate knowledge of social work theory and practice.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE IN SCHOOLS I

data.description: Practicum and supervision in school settings.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICUM IN SCHOOLS I

data.description: Practicum and supervision in school settings.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICUM IN SCHOOLS II

data.description: Preparation for leadership roles in mental health programs, agencies, and organizations. Examine mental health policies and services that influence care and treatment of persons with mental illness and shape mental health care systems, programs and services
data.title: MENTAL HEALTH POLICIES AND SERVICES

data.description: Prepares front line social workers to address mental health needs of older adults and their family members. Examines common mental health conditions, assessment, planning, evidence-based individual, family and group interventions, resources, cultural competence, ethical issues, and contexts for practice.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE IN AGING AND MENTAL HEALTH

data.description: Presentation of social, historical, legal, political, and ethical considerations surrounding the use and abuse of alcohol and psychotropic drugs in the U.S.
data.title: SUBSTANCE USE DISORDERS

data.description: Program of study devised by a student in collaboration with a faculty member.
data.title: DIRECTED STUDY

data.description: Provides a forum to discuss experiences, success strategies and research interests; receive feedback on research and later, on colloquia they prepare for job searches.
data.title: STUDENT RESEARCH SEMINAR

data.description: Provides an awareness of problems and concepts of the policy process in the U.S. Explores the political, economic, and institutional frameworks which structure public social welfare choices.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO SOCIAL POLICY

data.description: Provides knowledge about the contemporary organization of health care, as well as policies and services for older adults and people with disabilities.
data.title: HEALTH, AGING, AND DISABILITY POLICY AND SERVICES

data.description: Qualitative research methods seminars for research in the social and behavioral sciences.
data.title: PROSEMINAR

data.description: Quantitative research methods seminars for research in the social and behavioral sciences.
data.title: PROSEMINAR

data.description: Research methods and statistics used in analyzing planning problems: conceptualization, design, and implementation of planning research; statistical methods for analyzing data including review of inferential statistics, analysis of variance, correlation, and multiple regression; use of computer; review of sources of planning data.
data.title: METHODS OF PLANNING ANALYSIS

data.description: Review of family theory and its relevance for social work practice; an analysis of family subsystems in the U.S.; current research on the American family.
data.title: FAMILY PROBLEMS AND SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Second of two semesters of undergraduate research for students in the honors program including completion of a thesis.
data.title: SENIOR HONORS THESIS

data.description: Second of two semesters of undergraduate research including completion of a thesis.
data.title: SENIOR THESIS

data.description: Social policy seminars. Contemporary social welfare policy concerns are addressed utilizing a policy analytics framework. Poverty and Income Support Policy; Family Theory Policy; Child Development and Policy; and Social Determinants of Health and Policy are examples of topics offered.
data.title: PHD PROSEMINAR

data.description: Social research and problems of project design and programming. Distinctive characteristics of investigations directed to planning, administrative, and scientific objectives.
data.title: METHODS OF SOCIAL WORK RESEARCH

data.description: Supportive, supplementary, and substitute child welfare services employed in dealing with the problems of dependent, neglected, delinquent children. Scope, method, problems, trends of the services; child welfare in other countries; sociology of the child welfare worker.
data.title: CHILD WELFARE

data.description: The focus on Social Work political advocacy strategies in public policy and government settings. To best prepare social workers seeking to impact public policy and social change and improve the social and economic status of individuals, families, communities and systems, examine the knowledge and political skills, strategies, techniques and actions which influence elected officials and policy makers and the policies, practices, programs, services and resources they establish for people in need through local, state and federal units of government.
data.title: INFLUENCING POLITICAL SYSTEMS FOR SOCIAL CHANGE

data.description: The literature on human behavior and the environment is reviewed from a bio-psychosocial perspective. Special attention is given to understanding individual and family behavior and development as a function of reciprocal interactions with groups, communities, organizations, and society.
data.title: HUMAN BEHAVIOR AND THE ENVIRONMENT

data.description: The role of social workers and social services in American Indian and tribal communities, particularly compliance with the Indian Child Welfare Act. Historical context includes land removal and loss, the boarding school and adoption eras, and social determinants of health including the impacts of historical and intergenerational trauma.
data.title: SOCIAL WORK IN AMERICAN INDIAN COMMUNITIES: THE INDIAN CHILD WELFARE ACT

data.description: Theoretical, empirical and practical foundation for prevention science as it relates to the prevention of human social problems. Research and evaluation methods, program design strategies, best practices and policy as they relate to the field of prevention are also examined.
data.title: PREVENTION SCIENCE

data.description: Topics vary and focus on advanced practice.
data.title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Topics vary and focus on social problems/social issues.
data.title: RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN SOCIAL WORK

data.description: Topics will vary and designed to meet MSW Program requisites.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting current issues and trends in social justice, social welfare, and social work.
data.title: CONTEMPORARY ISSUES IN SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting current issues and trends in social justice, social welfare, and social work.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting emerging issues and trends in social work for social welfare, generalist and advanced practice students.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting issues and trends in social policy and social work.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting issues and trends in social work for non-social workers.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting new issues and trends in fields of practice such as child welfare, health, or mental health.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting new issues and trends in social justice, social welfare, or social work.
data.title: CONTEMPORARY ISSUES IN SOCIAL WELFARE

data.description: Topics will vary, reflecting social issues/social problems relevant to social welfare and social work.
data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE

data.title: TOPICS IN CONTEMPORARY SOCIAL WELFARE
